Award.AwardTitle: Increasing Student Engagement by Improving Social-cognitive Bias Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing and maintaining outstanding STEM workers is critical to America's global competitiveness. Innovation is limited when resources are untapped. Throughout the United States, there is a great demand for engineers and scientists who are well-trained and well-equipped for today's STEM workforce, including the engineering professoriate. This project seeks to design, implement, and study a faculty development program that addresses two major factors influencing student retention: (a) reducing the "chilly climate" that underrepresented engineering students' experience and (b) increasing active learning opportunities in the engineering classroom. Through the use of specialized readings, workshops, and small group discussions and activities, participating engineering faculty will be offered support on active learning instructional practices and on creating an inclusive learning environment for students from diverse backgrounds. This grant project is closely linked with current priorities of the National Science Foundation's Broadening Participation in Engineering program. By enhancing instruction and improving the engineering classroom climate, engineering faculty are likely to create more inclusive learning environments that may increase the number of underrepresented students who pursue engineering.

The investigators purport to develop a training program for engineering faculty that equip them with strategies and skills to reduce their social cognitive biases and the effects of such biases have on success outcomes for students, especially underrepresented student groups. Using a mixed-method research design, the results of the faculty development program will be analyzed at multiple levels to determine the impact the project had on engineering students and faculty. If successful, it has immense potential to improve engineering instruction and classroom climate in higher education across the country. To this end, all data collections will focus on the following:

(1) Faculty reactions to the program,
(2) Observed changes in instructional practice,
(3) Student experiences of the classroom climate,
(4) Student engagement in the classroom,
(5) Student engagement in subsequent courses, and
(6) Student retention in the engineering curriculum.

The project is targeting components of the effort that can be easily adapted by others, by identifying the limitations that exist and the resources that are needed to scale the effort. A website will be created to provide program information to the community and workshops are planned for meetings of the Engineering Deans Council and the SEC. The project will also leverage the ADVANCE Implementation Mentors (AIM) Network to connect with the representative institutions and further encourage adaptation of the effort's strategies and materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ultimate goal of "Improving Student Experiences to Increase Student Engagement" (ISE-2) was to increase engagement, success, and retention of engineering students, especially underrepresented ethnic minority (URM) students. ISE-2 designed, implemented, and studied a faculty development program that addressed two factors influencing student retention: (a) reducing the "chilly climate" that URM students experience and (b) increasing active learning opportunities in the classroom. Chilly climate was addressed through faculty development on social cognitive biases; our expectation was that increasing faculty knowledge on social cognitive biases would help them recognize microaggressions in the classroom and intervene, ultimately improving classroom climate. Further, development and deployment of active learning instructional strategies was expected to improve classroom climate and increase student engagement with peers and with their course material. Texas A&M's large and diverse student body and faculty allow for a strong test of the effects of this program.

The faculty development program consisted of readings, workshops, and small group discussions and activities. Fifteen engineering faculty who teach engineering courses in the first two years--the most critical years for improving success and retention of engineering students participated in the ISE-2 program.

The overarching hypothesis of this project was: by developing faculty knowledge on social cognitive biases and strategies to reduce them, as well as improving faculty skills in applying student-engaging instructional approaches, faculty will transform their instructional practices, which will in turn improve URM student engagement, success, and retention.

Five research questions elaborated the hypothesis and the research on the faculty development program evaluated its effect at multiple levels: (i) faculty reactions to the program, (ii) observed changes in instructional practice, (iii) student experiences of the classroom climate, (iv) student engagement in the classroom, (v) student engagement in subsequent courses, and (vi) student retention in the engineering curriculum.  The five questions were:

(1) To what extent do ISE-2 faculty change their instructional practices?

(2) How do student experiences of classroom climate (e.g. via microaggressions) in engineering courses taught by ISE-2 faculty compare with student experiences in the same courses taught by non-ISE-2 faculty?

(3) How does student engagement in engineering courses taught by ISE-2 faculty compare with student engagement in the same courses taught by non-ISE-2 faculty?

(4) Are students who took classes from ISE-2 faculty more engaged in their courses when they are juniors than students who took the same courses taught by other (non-ISE-2) faculty?

(5) How does student retention following engineering courses taught by ISE-2 faculty compare with student retention following the same courses taught by non-ISE-2 faculty?

 

Results

Regarding the first question, results indicated that faculty were more likely to recommend resources to students (e.g., writing center, tutoring center), connected more on an interpersonal levelwith students, and linked more concepts with information in other parts of the course following the program compared to before the program. They were also more likely to use discouraging comments, but this finding was limited by a change in our coding strategy. Faculty in the development program showed a sophisticated understanding of the material from the development program. 

Regarding the second and third questions, student survey data showed little difference between classrooms led by ISE-2 faculty and control group faculty.

Regarding the fourth and fifth question, these data are not yet available as we await the students who were in these classes to reach (a) their junior year and 4- and 6-year graduation dates.

 

Additional innovations and contributions

The project team also innovated a classroom observation tool. The Classroom Observation Protocol for Undergraduate STEM courses (COPUS; Smith, Jones, Gilbert, and Wieman, 2013) is designed for documenting the behaviors and interactions of faculty and students in STEM classrooms. Additionally, the tool is designed so that observers do not need expertise in the content of the course in order to conduct the observation. 

We expanded on the COPUS in one key way, which allowed for a critical improvement in the use of the COPUS. First, instead of using the COPUS in situ during a classroom observation, we instead took comprehensive and detailed notes using an environmental scan. In the scan, we wrote minute-by-minute notes of classroom behavior and interactions. Them we coded the scan into the COPUS coding scheme. Because of the environmental scan, we were able to then identify themes that were not present in the COPUS but appeared important in our classroom observations. For example, our emergent codes identified topics such as "Using Texas A&M specific language and examples" and "Linking concepts from different parts of the course to the current material."

We propagated our methodological innovation in a poster presented at the ASEE 2019 conference, with a paper published in the conference proceedings. Additionally, we created a DIY toolkit to self-teach this expanded methodology. The QR code to link to this toolkit appears in the "DIY classroom observation toolkit" attached to this report.
